author: Hannah Ellis-Petersen
title: Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr come together for musical collaboration | Music | The Guardian
text:
Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr come together for musical collaboration 
McCartney played bass on his fellow Beatleâ€™s upcoming new album, their first recording in seven years The two had not made music together for 7 years. Photograph: Ringo Starr/Twitter/PA View more sharing options Monday 20 February 2017 16.00 GMT Last modified on Monday 20 February 2017 16.03 GMT 
The two surviving members of the Beatles have recorded music together for the first time in seven years. 
Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr released pictures of themselves in Starrâ€™s home studio over the weekend. McCartney will be making a guest appearance on Starrâ€™s latest record, a follow-up to 2015â€™s Postcards from Paradise. 
Starr took to Twitter to thank his former bandmate for joining him in the studio. â€œThanks for coming over man and playing great bass,â€ Starr wrote. â€œI love you man â€“ peace and love.â€ #RingoStarr (@ringostarrmusic) Thanks for coming over man and playing Great bass. I love you man peace and love. ğŸ˜âœŒï¸ğŸŒŸğŸ’–ğŸ˜‡â˜® pic.twitter.com/Z5kpyLLlkO February 20, 2017 
Also joining the former Beatles in the studio was Eagles guitarist Joe Walsh, who Starr said had â€œcome out to playâ€. 
Bruce Sugar, who is producing Starrâ€™s latest album, posted a photo of him with McCartney and Starr on Facebook, with the caption: â€œMagical day in the studio today with these two.â€ 
It is the first time since 2010 that the pair have collaborated to make music, when McCartney played bass on Starrâ€™s track Peace Dream, and contributed his vocals to Walk With You. 
Starr confirmed he was working on a new record last year, but said a release date was still not scheduled.
